did.head: Descriptive Summary

repository.label: Repository
repository.corpname: Stanford University. Libraries. Dept. of Special Collections and University Archives.

did.abstract: Correspondence, particularly with Harry Gamboa, Jr., Gloria Molina, Edward James Olmos, Cesar Chavez, Dolores Huerta, and Robert Rodriguez, original artwork, material about Cesar Chavez and the UFW, publications about Mexican American art and her own work including issues of Chismearte, Coraz?n de Aztl?n, Americas 2001, Caminos, and La Raza Magazine, photographs and videos.
did.langmaterial: Languages represented in the collection: English

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: Collection is open for research; materials must be requested at least 24 hours in advance of intended use.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: Property rights reside with the repository. Literary rights reside with the creators of the documents or their heirs. To obtain permission to publish or reproduce, please contact the Public Services Librarian of the Dept. of Special Collections.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Barbara Carrasco papers, M0880. Dept. of Special Collections, Stanford University Libraries, Stanford, Calif.

bioghist.head: Biography / Administrative History
bioghist.p: Barbara Carrasco is a painter and muralist in Los Angeles whose work has been important in the development of Chicano art, U.S. contemporary political and public art, and women's cultural production. Her art has been collected in the Library of Congress and the Smithsonian Institution.
Between 1976 and 1991, Carrasco worked closely with Cesar Chavez and the United Farm Workers (UFW), producing graphic arts, banners, and murals that were an integral part of the union's activities.

In the early 1980's, Carrasco was at the center of an intense battle over artistics censorship with the Community Redevelopment Agency of the City of Los Angeles, which refused to exhibit her portable mural "L.A. History -- A Mexican Perspective".
Carrasco's other murals include the centerpiece for Luis Valdez's play, Zoot Suit (1978), and a computer animation "mural" on pesticides displayed on the big screen monitor in Times Square.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: The collection contains correspondence, particularly with Harry Gamboa, Jr., Gloria Molina, Edward James Olmos, Cesar Chavez, Dolores Huerta, and Robert Rodrigue; original artwork; material about Cesar Chavez and the UFW; publications about Mexican American art and her own work including issues of Chismearte, Corazon de Aztlan, Americas 2001, Caminos, and La Raza Magazine, photographs and videos.

scopecontent.p: Contains papers relating to the CARA exhibition; an interview with Manazar Gamboa; manuscripts for articles written by Carrasco; information on various conferences and symposia in which Carrasco participated; and sketches, notes, and correspondence relating to various murals done by Carrasco.

scopecontent.p: Contains correspondence from Cesar Chavez, Dolores Huerta; drawings by various UFW members, including one by Cesar Chavez; photographs of UFW art and banners which were subsequently destroyed; miscellaneous reports and petitions relating to the UFW; and clippings.
Includes Oscar Mondragon

scopecontent.p: Contains letters, memos, and notes regarding the Masters of Fine Arts degree, including letters of support from Dolores Huerta and Peter Sellars regarding graduation controversy and an audiotape of the review committee meeting discussing the controversy. Also contains Carrasco's Master of Fine Arts project file, and an audiotape and photographs of a staged confrontation with Henry Gamboa, Jr. in a classroom.
Transcription of telephone interview

scopecontent.p: Contains letters, photograph, and memorabilia relating to Carrasco's visit to Nicaragua in 1986. Also includes a sketch of Sandinista general.
Contains correspondence, student papers, and administrative materials relating to Carrasco's teaching activities.

scopecontent.p: Contains books, exhibition catalogs, and magazines featuring Carrasco and/or her artwork, including multiple issues of Chismearte, Corazon de Aztlan, Americas 2001, High Performance, Art X Press, Pro Fun, Framework, Community Murals, and Caminos.
